  • SUBARU - Outback/Legacy/Forester
  • VOLVO - V70
  • TOYOTA - Prius, Corolla, Camry, (any Toyota)
  • HONDA - Accord, Civic, (any of the ACURA options also)
  • AUDI - any of the wagons/hatches.

Do you need a Warranty: No

Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No

Additional Notes:

I'm a 32 year old male. I currently work from home ~ half of each month, and the other ~ half I commute to various work locations (usually between 1-20 miles each way). Uber/Lyft/Rental cars cost me about $2500/year, but I anticipate that cost increasing as I take on some additional study.

I like to take camping trips in SoCal and I'd love the opportunity to travel around the West Coast of America. Not having a car has significantly reduced the amount of time I spend outside, and is another main reason why I'm looking to purchase a car.

I want to spend the least money possible, over the next 5 or so years. I like my mechanic, but I don't like spending a lot of money or time at his shop (I get probably rules out the AUDI/other foreign makes...).

I value functionality over fashion (as much as one can in LA). I sometimes need to transport gear for work.

I'm sure there's more, but I hope that's a good starting point!

Thanks!

• Location: Raleigh, NC
  • Price range: I have a big chunk to put down ($40k) and will finance the rest. Thinking of sticking around $55k or so top end so that my payments can stay pretty low
  • Lease or Buy: Buy
  • New or used: Either (probably very lightly used, open to new for the right car/price)
  • Type of vehicle: Sedan, GT (4 seat coupe), Wagon, Hatchback
  • Must haves: Sporty (300 hp or more, 5 or fewer seconds 0-60, good driving feel), RWD or AWD only, practicality, adaptive cruise control, other driver aids if possible, comfortable leather interior with heated and preferably ventilated seats, would like to be able to tune and modify after warranty runs out (or maybe before if they are subtle) The most important thing to me is comfort and tech/driver aids, then performance, closely followed by practicality/size
  • Desired transmission (auto/manual, etc): Automatic
  • Intended use: Daily Driver for commuting, trips to DC and 180-200 mile round trips to vacation home, must fit a medium to large dog, would like rear space but not necessary at this point in my life
  • Vehicles you've already considered: A4 wagons (Allroad), Genesis G70 Sport, 3 Series wagon, m340i/c43 amg/S4 (I don’t like the look of the S5 sport back or whatever it’s called), Tesla Model 3, Golf R
  • Is this your 1st vehicle: No, but will replace my only vehicle
  • Do you need a Warranty: probably yes
  • Can you do Minor work on your own vehicle: Very minor, yes, and would love to learn to do more. I don’t have a garage but I do have a large enough driveway to do basic things
  • Can you do Major work on your own vehicle: No Additional Notes: I currently drive a Mercedes C250 sedan that will last a good few years still, but I would like to replace it in the next couple of months. Basically I am looking for a well rounded, sporty, comfortable, practical, and unique-ish sedan, large coupe, wagon, or hatchback. I’ve posted here before and got predictable feedback (not a knock, I appreciate all the responses I get!). I’m particularly interested in the G70 3.3T Sport due to its performance and incredible value. Similarly optioned German competitors would run $15-20k more out the door so it seems like a no-brainer. What I really need is someone to try to talk me out of the genesis, and/or other suggestions of cars with the same level of tech and comfort and performance and practicality rolled into one. I love the idea of driving a c43, especially the gorgeous coupe, but I hate the idea of paying to maintain and repair one. If the G70 had a coupe counterpart I would probably already own it. Another thing that has tripped me up is the recent spy shots of the G70 facelift in Korea- anyone know how long until we might see what it looks like? If anyone has experience owning any of the above mentioned cars or anything similar, I would love to hear what it’s been like to own, how often it’s been in for maintenance/repair, general cost of ownership, any insight you can provide. Thanks very much!!

The thing I want most in a car is that I don't have to worry about it too much and overall ownership costs (gas/insurance/repairs) aren't high. I intend to run this car into the ground. I'm also interested in older cars (10 years +) but I'm concerned that there's a risk that I might have to go to the shop for problems more than once a year (excluding routine stuff like oil changes) if the car is too old/too high mileage. If an older car might make more sense for what I want to do, then I guess I'd be able to save $5,000 or more.

I plan to drive around 15,000 miles a year. Currently I've been doing calculations based on the assumption that I'll get rid of the car by the time it hits around 200-250k miles, and as such a CPO vehicle that costs 15k with 30k miles actually has a cost basis per year that's very similar to a car that's 5k less but has 80k miles, with the upside of having less worries overall. One thing I'm worried about is that these calculations are based on driving the same car for 10+ years, and I don't know if I'm willing to drive a Corolla or Prius for so long. 5 years for sure, but 10? 15? I don't know. If my assumptions are wrong then let me know.

In terms of prior experience, when I've needed to drive, I drive my parents' Toyota Highlander (2003) or Camry Hybrid (2013).
